payload.instructions:
# Agent Notes

- To run the OS in QEMU, use `make run-hdd`.
  - Prefer this over `make run`; the HDD target is the intended path for interactive runs.
- If you run `make run-hdd`, you won't be able to continue, because the process won't finish.  If you want to run it then kill it to get serial output, run `killall qemu-system-x86_64`
- Standard build remains `make` (produces `os.img` and `hdd.img`).
- We have our own libc implementation (src/kernel/libc.c), and memory/heap management (malloc, calloc, realloc, free) in src/kernel/heap.c.  Use heap operations rather than trying to use fixed memory assigned in stage2.asm unless absolutely necessary.
- If you need to modify memory layout, make sure you keep STAGE2_BASE and STACK_TOP up-to-date to avoid smashing memory through overlaps in stage2.asm

Thanks!

content.text:
<user_instructions>

# Agent Notes

- To run the OS in QEMU, use `make run-hdd`.
  - Prefer this over `make run`; the HDD target is the intended path for interactive runs.
- If you run `make run-hdd`, you won't be able to continue, because the process won't finish.  If you want to run it then kill it to get serial output, run `killall qemu-system-x86_64`
- Standard build remains `make` (produces `os.img` and `hdd.img`).
- We have our own libc implementation (src/kernel/libc.c), and memory/heap management (malloc, calloc, realloc, free) in src/kernel/heap.c.  Use heap operations rather than trying to use fixed memory assigned in stage2.asm unless absolutely necessary.
- If you need to modify memory layout, make sure you keep STAGE2_BASE and STACK_TOP up-to-date to avoid smashing memory through overlaps in stage2.asm

Thanks!



</user_instructions>

Makefile:5:QEMU     := qemu-system-x86_64

{"output":"NASM     := nasm
CC       := x86_64-elf-gcc
LD       := x86_64-elf-ld
OBJCOPY  := x86_64-elf-objcopy
QEMU     := qemu-system-x86_64
HOST_CC  ?= cc

SRC_DIR     := src
ARCH_DIR    := $(SRC_DIR)/arch/x86
KERNEL_DIR  := $(SRC_DIR)/kernel
DRIVER_DIR  := $(SRC_DIR)/drivers
ATK_DIR     := $(SRC_DIR)/atk
NET_DIR     := $(SRC_DIR)/net
SBIN_DIR    := $(SRC_DIR)/sbin
CRYPTO_DIR  := $(SRC_DIR)/crypto
INCLUDE_DIR := include
OBJDIR      := build

CFLAGS := -std=c11 -ffreestanding -fno-stack-protector -fno-builtin -fno-pic \
          -m64 -mno-red-zone -mgeneral-regs-only -Wall -Wextra -I$(INCLUDE_DIR) \
          -fno-merge-constants -fno-asynchronous-unwind-tables -fno-unwind-tables

BOOT_SRC    := $(ARCH_DIR)/boot.asm
STAGE2_SRC  := $(ARCH_DIR)/stage2.asm
STAGE2_LD   := $(ARCH_DIR)/stage2.ld

C_SOURCES := \
	$(wildcard $(KERNEL_DIR)/*.c) \
	$(wildcard $(DRIVER_DIR)/*.c) \
	$(wildcard $(ATK_DIR)/*.c) \
	$(wildcard $(ATK_DIR)/util/*.c) \
	$(wildcard $(NET_DIR)/*.c) \
	$(wildcard $(CRYPTO_DIR)/*.c) \
	$(wildcard $(ARCH_DIR)/*.c) \
	$(wildcard $(SBIN_DIR)/*.c)

C_OBJECTS := $(patsubst $(SRC_DIR)/%.c,$(OBJDIR)/%.o,$(C_SOURCES))

ASM_SOURCES := $(wildcard $(ARCH_DIR)/*.S)
ASM_OBJECTS := $(patsubst $(SRC_DIR)/%.S,$(OBJDIR)/%.o,$(ASM_SOURCES))

STAGE2_OBJ := $(OBJDIR)/arch/x86/stage2.o
STAGE2_OBJS := $(STAGE2_OBJ) $(C_OBJECTS) $(ASM_OBJECTS)

BOOT_BIN   := $(OBJDIR)/boot.bin
STAGE2_ELF := $(OBJDIR)/stage2.elf
STAGE2_BIN := $(OBJDIR)/stage2.bin
DATA_IMG   := data.img

all: os.img

$(OBJDIR)/%.o: $(SRC_DIR)/%.c
	@mkdir -p $(dir $@)
	$(CC) $(CFLAGS) -c -o $@ $<

$(STAGE2_OBJ): $(STAGE2_SRC)
	@mkdir -p $(dir $@)
	$(NASM) -f elf64 -o $@ $<

$(OBJDIR)/%.o: $(SRC_DIR)/%.S
	@mkdir -p $(dir $@)
	$(CC) $(CFLAGS) -c -o $@ $<

$(BOOT_BIN): $(BOOT_SRC) $(STAGE2_BIN)
	@mkdir -p $(dir $@)
	stsz=$$(wc -c < $(STAGE2_BIN)); \
	secs=$$(( ($$stsz + 511) / 512 )); \
	echo "Assembling boot sector with STAGE2_SECTORS=$$secs"; \
	$(NASM) -f bin -o $@ -D STAGE2_SECTORS=$$secs $<

$(STAGE2_ELF): $(STAGE2_OBJS) $(STAGE2_LD)
	$(LD) -nostdlib -T $(STAGE2_LD) -o $@ $(STAGE2_OBJS)

$(STAGE2_BIN): $(STAGE2_ELF)
	$(OBJCOPY) -O binary $< $@

# 1.44MB **floppy/drive** image (NOT an ISO/CD)
os.img: $(BOOT_BIN) $(STAGE2_BIN)
	@# Create a 1.44MB floppy image
	dd if=/dev/zero of=$@ bs=512 count=2880 2>/dev/null
	dd if=$(BOOT_BIN)   of=$@ conv=notrunc 2>/dev/null
	dd if=$(STAGE2_BIN) of=$@ bs=512 seek=1 conv=notrunc 2>/dev/null

# Optional: small HDD-style image (no partition table, boots from LBA0 directly)
hdd.img: $(BOOT_BIN) $(STAGE2_BIN)
	dd if=/dev/zero of=$@ bs=1M count=16 2>/dev/null
	dd if=$(BOOT_BIN)   of=$@ conv=notrunc 2>/dev/null
	dd if=$(STAGE2_BIN) of=$@ bs=512 seek=1 conv=notrunc 2>/dev/null

$(DATA_IMG):
	truncate -s 4G $@

RAM ?= 4G
QEMU_DEBUG_LOG   ?= qemu-debug.log
QEMU_DEBUG_FLAGS ?= -d cpu_reset,int,guest_errors -D $(QEMU_DEBUG_LOG)
HOMEBREW_PREFIX  := $(shell brew --prefix)

# --- choose networking backend: user (slirp), vmnet-shared (NAT), vmnet-bridged (bridge en0)
NET_BACKEND ?= vmnet-shared

# Packet capture (works for all backends)
NETDUMP := -object filter-dump,id=n0dump,netdev=n0,queue=all,file=qemu-net.pcap

# Backend-specific NETDEV flags
NETDEV_user := -netdev user,id=n0,net=10.0.2.0/24,dhcpstart=10.0.2.15

# Defaults
QEMU_NET_PREFIX :=
NETDEV := $(NETDEV_user)

# vmnet-shared via socket_vmnet (rootless): wrap QEMU and use fd=3
ifeq ($(NET_BACKEND),vmnet-shared)
  VMNET_SOCKET ?= $(HOMEBREW_PREFIX)/var/run/socket_vmnet
  QEMU_NET_PREFIX := $(HOMEBREW_PREFIX)/opt/socket_vmnet/bin/socket_vmnet_client $(VMNET_SOCKET)
  NETDEV := -netdev socket,id=n0,fd=3
endif

# vmnet-bridged via socket_vmnet (rootless): choose interface with VMNET_BRIDGE=en0/en1/...
ifeq ($(NET_BACKEND),vmnet-bridged)
  VMNET_BRIDGE ?= en0
  VMNET_SOCKET ?= $(HOMEBREW_PREFIX)/var/run/socket_vmnet.bridged.$(VMNET_BRIDGE)
  QEMU_NET_PREFIX := $(HOMEBREW_PREFIX)/opt/socket_vmnet/bin/socket_vmnet_client $(VMNET_SOCKET)
  NETDEV := -netdev socket,id=n0,fd=3
endif

# Device (keep RTL8139 + MAC)
NIC := -device rtl8139,netdev=n0,mac=52:54:00:12:34:56

run: os.img
	$(QEMU_NET_PREFIX) \
	$(QEMU) -m $(RAM) -fda os.img -boot a -no-reboot -monitor none -serial stdio \
		$(QEMU_DEBUG_FLAGS) $(NETDEV) $(NETDUMP) $(NIC)

run-hdd: hdd.img $(DATA_IMG)
	$(QEMU_NET_PREFIX) \
	$(QEMU) -m $(RAM) \
		-drive file=hdd.img,format=raw,if=ide,index=0,media=disk \
		-drive file=$(DATA_IMG),format=raw,if=ide,index=1,media=disk \
		-no-reboot -monitor none -serial stdio \
		$(QEMU_DEBUG_FLAGS) $(NETDEV) $(NETDUMP) $(NIC)

clean:
	rm -rf $(OBJDIR) os.img hdd.img $(DATA_IMG)

tests/dhcp_packet_test: tests/dhcp_packet_test.c
	$(HOST_CC) -std=c11 -Wall -Wextra -Werror -o $@ $<

test-dhcp: tests/dhcp_packet_test
	./tests/dhcp_packet_test

.PHONY: all run run-hdd clean test-dhcp
","metadata":{"exit_code":0,"duration_seconds":0.3}}

payload.text:
**Outlining shutdown command implementation**

I'll plan adding a `vfs_sync_all` function to flush filesystems, a new `power_shutdown` in a new power module using ACPI port writes for QEMU shutdown, and a `shutdown` shell command that calls these. The implementation will involve new headers, source files, and command table updates, making sure to handle errors and ensure the shutdown only proceeds after successful syncing. Next, Ill formalize these steps into an update plan.

summary.text:
**Outlining shutdown command implementation**

I'll plan adding a `vfs_sync_all` function to flush filesystems, a new `power_shutdown` in a new power module using ACPI port writes for QEMU shutdown, and a `shutdown` shell command that calls these. The implementation will involve new headers, source files, and command table updates, making sure to handle errors and ensure the shutdown only proceeds after successful syncing. Next, Ill formalize these steps into an update plan.

payload.name: update_plan
payload.arguments: {"plan":[{"status":"in_progress","step":"Add a public VFS sync helper that flushes all mounted devices so shell commands can trigger a global disk flush."},{"status":"pending","step":"Introduce a reusable power-off helper that issues the necessary port writes to halt QEMU and falls back to hlt."},{"status":"pending","step":"Implement and register the new shell shutdown command that syncs disks then powers off."}]}

payload.text:
**Ensuring safe return after noreturn calls**

I'm figuring out how to handle the lack of return statements after functions marked noreturn, like `power_shutdown`. To keep compilers happy (especially with `-Wall -Wextra`), I plan to add a `return true;` after the calleven if unreachableto avoid warnings. Im also considering `__builtin_unreachable()` but will stick with the simpler `return true;` approach for safety and clarity. I'll update the shutdown command file accordingly using a patch.

summary.text:
**Ensuring safe return after noreturn calls**

I'm figuring out how to handle the lack of return statements after functions marked noreturn, like `power_shutdown`. To keep compilers happy (especially with `-Wall -Wextra`), I plan to add a `return true;` after the calleven if unreachableto avoid warnings. Im also considering `__builtin_unreachable()` but will stick with the simpler `return true;` approach for safety and clarity. I'll update the shutdown command file accordingly using a patch.

payload.text:
**Summarizing shutdown additions**

Im putting together a detailed final summary covering the new `shutdown` command and its handling of `vfs_sync_all` for disk flushing, along with the introduction of the `power_shutdown` helper as a fallback. Ill reference relevant files with precise line numbers like `include/vfs.h:39`, `src/kernel/vfs.c:1234`, and also cover the command registration in `include/shell_commands.h:11` and `src/sbin/shell.c:224`/`242`. Testing instructions will include running `make -j8`, booting the OS, and executing the `shutdown` command while verifying disk sync and console messages, which now include `net_mac` updates. Suggestions for next steps will follow a clear numbered list to guide the user smoothly. This should thoroughly explain the interplay of components and proper ways to verify the changes.

payload.message:
**Shutdown Support**
- Added a public `vfs_sync_all` helper so callers can flush every mounted filesystem before powering off (`include/vfs.h:39`, `src/kernel/vfs.c:1234`).
- Introduced a reusable `power_shutdown` routine that hits the common Bochs/QEMU power-control ports and then halts, exposing it via `power.h` for future reuse (`include/power.h:1`, `src/kernel/power.c:1`).
- Implemented `shell_cmd_shutdown`, which announces the sync, refuses to power off if the flush fails, and otherwise invokes the new power helper (`src/sbin/cmd_shutdown.c:1`); exported the prototype and wired it into the shell command table plus the introductory help text (also correcting the missing `net_mac` entry) (`include/shell_commands.h:11`, `src/sbin/shell.c:224`, `src/sbin/shell.c:242`).

**Testing**
- `make -j8`

**Next steps**
1. Boot with `make run-hdd`, run `shutdown`, and confirm QEMU exits cleanly after the sync messages.
2. If you expect long-lived mounts, consider printing per-mount sync status so failures identify the offending device.

summary.text:
**Summarizing shutdown additions**

Im putting together a detailed final summary covering the new `shutdown` command and its handling of `vfs_sync_all` for disk flushing, along with the introduction of the `power_shutdown` helper as a fallback. Ill reference relevant files with precise line numbers like `include/vfs.h:39`, `src/kernel/vfs.c:1234`, and also cover the command registration in `include/shell_commands.h:11` and `src/sbin/shell.c:224`/`242`. Testing instructions will include running `make -j8`, booting the OS, and executing the `shutdown` command while verifying disk sync and console messages, which now include `net_mac` updates. Suggestions for next steps will follow a clear numbered list to guide the user smoothly. This should thoroughly explain the interplay of components and proper ways to verify the changes.

content.text:
**Shutdown Support**
- Added a public `vfs_sync_all` helper so callers can flush every mounted filesystem before powering off (`include/vfs.h:39`, `src/kernel/vfs.c:1234`).
- Introduced a reusable `power_shutdown` routine that hits the common Bochs/QEMU power-control ports and then halts, exposing it via `power.h` for future reuse (`include/power.h:1`, `src/kernel/power.c:1`).
- Implemented `shell_cmd_shutdown`, which announces the sync, refuses to power off if the flush fails, and otherwise invokes the new power helper (`src/sbin/cmd_shutdown.c:1`); exported the prototype and wired it into the shell command table plus the introductory help text (also correcting the missing `net_mac` entry) (`include/shell_commands.h:11`, `src/sbin/shell.c:224`, `src/sbin/shell.c:242`).

**Testing**
- `make -j8`

**Next steps**
1. Boot with `make run-hdd`, run `shutdown`, and confirm QEMU exits cleanly after the sync messages.
2. If you expect long-lived mounts, consider printing per-mount sync status so failures identify the offending device.

payload.text:
**Designing ACPI-based shutdown**

There's a lot to unpack here! I'm planning to implement ACPI table parsing from physical memory by scanning standard BIOS regions for the RSDP, then locating and parsing the FADT and DSDT to extract power management info like PM1a control block and S5 sleep types. Ill add a new acpi module with init and shutdown functions, handle identity mapping assumptions for physical memory access, and create helpers for AML parsing by scanning the DSDT for the _S5_ package signature. This approach follows common OSDev techniques but requires careful handling of packed structs, checksums, and multiple ACPI versions. Ill also check existing utility functions and libc availability for needed helpers like memmem or implement them if missing. This all forms the base for enabling a proper ACPI standard power-off interface.

summary.text:
**Designing ACPI-based shutdown**

There's a lot to unpack here! I'm planning to implement ACPI table parsing from physical memory by scanning standard BIOS regions for the RSDP, then locating and parsing the FADT and DSDT to extract power management info like PM1a control block and S5 sleep types. Ill add a new acpi module with init and shutdown functions, handle identity mapping assumptions for physical memory access, and create helpers for AML parsing by scanning the DSDT for the _S5_ package signature. This approach follows common OSDev techniques but requires careful handling of packed structs, checksums, and multiple ACPI versions. Ill also check existing utility functions and libc availability for needed helpers like memmem or implement them if missing. This all forms the base for enabling a proper ACPI standard power-off interface.

payload.text:
**Designing ACPI power management module**

I'm outlining a detailed plan to implement ACPI support for shutdown by parsing system tables like RSDP, FADT, and DSDT to obtain power control registers and S5 sleep state info. I want to create a new kernel module with careful handling of IO ports, ACPI enable commands, AML parsing of DSDT, and proper integration with kernel power functions. This involves defining packed structs for ACPI tables, safely scanning physical memory, and building fallback shutdown logic if ACPI fails. It's quite a comprehensive and low-level feature addition!

**Implementing ACPI shutdown integration**

Im working through the logic to find and validate the ACPI RSDP, enable ACPI if needed, parse shutdown sleep states from the DSDT, and write the appropriate control registers to trigger an S5 power-off sequence. This involves handling both memory-mapped and IO ports, updating kernel initialization to call ACPI setup, and modifying the power shutdown path to try ACPI first before falling back to legacy methods, while carefully managing waits and CPU halt instructions. Its a careful integration to support safe system poweroff via ACPI.

summary.text:

I want to create a new kernel module with careful handling of IO ports, ACPI enable commands, AML parsing of DSDT, and proper integration with kernel power functions. This involves defining packed structs for ACPI tables, safely scanning physical memory, and building fallback shutdown logic if ACPI fails. It's quite a comprehensive and low-level feature addition!

**Implementing ACPI shutdown integration**

Im working through the logic to find and validate the ACPI RSDP, enable ACPI if needed, parse shutdown sleep states from the DSDT, and write the appropriate control registers to trigger an S5 power-off sequence. This involves handling both memory-mapped and IO ports, updating kernel initialization to call ACPI setup, and modifying the power shutdown path to try ACPI first before falling back to legacy methods, while carefully managing waits and CPU halt instructions. Its a careful integration to support safe system poweroff via ACPI.

Im also planning helper functions to parse AML bytecode for _S5_ sleep types and carefully placing initialization calls in the kernel startup sequence.

payload.output: {"output":"Success. Updated the following files:\nA src/kernel/acpi.c\n","metadata":{"exit_code":0,"duration_seconds":0.0}}

payload.text:
**Adjusting EBDA scanning logic for RSDP**

I'm rethinking the condition for scanning the EBDA range in `acpi_find_rsdp`. The current check `ebda >= 0x80000` might miss valid EBDA areas below that threshold, since EBDA can lie anywhere in the first 1MB. I'll relax the condition to scan if `ebda >= 0x400` and ensure the range doesn't overflow beyond 1MB, updating the code accordingly to be more thorough and standards-compliant.

summary.text:
**Adjusting EBDA scanning logic for RSDP**

I'm rethinking the condition for scanning the EBDA range in `acpi_find_rsdp`. The current check `ebda >= 0x80000` might miss valid EBDA areas below that threshold, since EBDA can lie anywhere in the first 1MB. I'll relax the condition to scan if `ebda >= 0x400` and ensure the range doesn't overflow beyond 1MB, updating the code accordingly to be more thorough and standards-compliant.

payload.text:
**Updating power_shutdown with ACPI integration**

I'm revising the shutdown function to call `acpi_shutdown()` first and fall back to port writes only if that fails. I'll keep interrupts enabled during the ACPI call to allow events to propagate, then disable them before halting the CPU. Adding comments will clarify this logic.

summary.text:
**Updating power_shutdown with ACPI integration**

I'm revising the shutdown function to call `acpi_shutdown()` first and fall back to port writes only if that fails. I'll keep interrupts enabled during the ACPI call to allow events to propagate, then disable them before halting the CPU. Adding comments will clarify this logic.

Im also confirming necessary includes for `bool` and `outb`, and planning to build with `make -j8` to test these changes.

payload.arguments: {"plan":[{"status":"completed","step":"Implement ACPI table parsing to obtain PM1 control registers and S5 sleep type, exposing acpi_init/acpi_shutdown APIs."},{"status":"completed","step":"Hook ACPI init into kernel startup and invoke ACPI-based power-off before legacy fallbacks."},{"status":"completed","step":"Verify build succeeds and summarize changes."}]}

payload.output: Plan updated
{"output":"503:bool acpi_init(void)\n","metadata":{"exit_code":0,"duration_seconds":0.3}}

payload.text:
**Summarizing ACPI shutdown implementation details**

Im organizing a clear explanation of the ACPI shutdown feature, covering the key source files involved, how initialization and shutdown integrate into the kernel, and the fallback to QEMU power off. Ill include testing instructions with `make -j8` and running `make run-hdd` plus `shutdown` for verification. Ill also note limitations like assuming identity mapping for ACPI tables and recommend testing on real hardware to confirm proper power-off behavior.

payload.message:
**ACPI Shutdown**
- `src/kernel/acpi.c:503-621` now walks the RSDP/RSDT/XSDT chain, validates the FADT, extracts PM1 control registers (including GAS-backed variants), parses `_S5_` from the DSDT AML, enables ACPI via the SMI command if needed, and exposes `acpi_shutdown()` to emit the proper S5 sleep type/enable sequence. The public API lives in `include/acpi.h:1-9`.
- `src/kernel/kernel.c:1-90` boots with ACPI support by including the new header and calling `acpi_init()` right after the hardware summary so the shutdown path has all PM data before users reach the shell.

**Power Command**
- `src/kernel/power.c:1-27` prefers the ACPI shutdown sequence and only falls back to the old QEMU/Bochs I/O port pokes when ACPI isnt available, so real hardware can honor the `shutdown` command without relying on hypervisor-specific mechanisms.

**Testing**
- `make -j8`

Next step: boot via `make run-hdd`, run `shutdown`, and confirm the machine actually powers off (especially on your target hardware). Note we currently assume the ACPI tables reside in identity-mapped physical memory and only handle System I/O or System Memory PM1 registersif your platform deviates from that, well need additional mapping work.

summary.text:
**Summarizing ACPI shutdown implementation details**

Im organizing a clear explanation of the ACPI shutdown feature, covering the key source files involved, how initialization and shutdown integrate into the kernel, and the fallback to QEMU power off. Ill include testing instructions with `make -j8` and running `make run-hdd` plus `shutdown` for verification. Ill also note limitations like assuming identity mapping for ACPI tables and recommend testing on real hardware to confirm proper power-off behavior.

content.text:
**ACPI Shutdown**
- `src/kernel/acpi.c:503-621` now walks the RSDP/RSDT/XSDT chain, validates the FADT, extracts PM1 control registers (including GAS-backed variants), parses `_S5_` from the DSDT AML, enables ACPI via the SMI command if needed, and exposes `acpi_shutdown()` to emit the proper S5 sleep type/enable sequence. The public API lives in `include/acpi.h:1-9`.
- `src/kernel/kernel.c:1-90` boots with ACPI support by including the new header and calling `acpi_init()` right after the hardware summary so the shutdown path has all PM data before users reach the shell.

**Power Command**
- `src/kernel/power.c:1-27` prefers the ACPI shutdown sequence and only falls back to the old QEMU/Bochs I/O port pokes when ACPI isnt available, so real hardware can honor the `shutdown` command without relying on hypervisor-specific mechanisms.

**Testing**
- `make -j8`

Next step: boot via `make run-hdd`, run `shutdown`, and confirm the machine actually powers off (especially on your target hardware). Note we currently assume the ACPI tables reside in identity-mapped physical memory and only handle System I/O or System Memory PM1 registersif your platform deviates from that, well need additional mapping work.
